results.title: Fuel crisis
results.brief_description: The end of the petrol shortages and the promise of North Sea oil have led many people to believe that the crisis is over. The film shatters that illusion. Forecasts sizeable and increasing energy shortages for the 1980’s which could have traumatic political and economic effects on society

results.title: Frying methods
results.creator_credit: Dennis Shand, Gas Council and Film Workshop
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the following methods of frying foods: deep frying, shallow frying, dry frying and the frying of sweet dishes. Vegetables, fish, eggs, steak, bacon and port are some of the foods used in this film.

results.title: Frustration and fixation
results.creator_credit: Paul Ellen, Robert S. Feldman and University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Laboratory of Psychometric & Evaluation Research
results.brief_description: Documents Maier’s thesis that frustration leads to fixation and other bizarre sysmptoms. Shows a modified Lashley jumping apparatus and describes the process of teaching rats to jump. Frustrated animals finally assigned to soluble problems persist in fixations in spite of opening correct doors, and although walking trials demonstrate that they know the correct choice. Includes demonstrations of catatonic and neurotic behaviour.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Ellen, Robert S. Feldman and University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Laboratory of Psychometric & Evaluation Research

results.title: Fruitvale Station
results.brief_description: The true story of Oscar, a 22-year-old Bay Area resident, who crosses paths with friends, enemies, family, and strangers on the last day of 2008.

constellations_other.name: Confronting injustice on-screen
constellations_other.description: The Black Lives Matter movement and the treatment of African Americans at the hands of authorities is explored in this Constellation that connects hip-hop, the Civil Rights Movement and representation in Hollywood.

results.title: Fruits, vegetables and co-operation
results.brief_description: Bill shows his fellow-farmers, by means of films, how other farmers are benefiting by marketing their crops co-operatively. Jake, an ultra-conservative, offers many objections to this method, but he is finally won over to the idea of starting a local co-operative society on a small scale. Such crops as celery, lettuce, apples and citrus fruits are grown and marketed co-operatively with great success.

results.title: Fruit fly
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Mediterranean fruit fly is a serious pest of the fruit industry in Western Australia. It infests so many different types of fruit that it keeps alive throughout the seasons. It is the larvae that do the damage. It is necessary to keep orchards absolutely clean. One dirty orchard can affect the whole district.

results.title: Frozen music
results.brief_description: This film is an examination of the thoughts and aspirations of the Victorian ruling class mentality as revealed through the Albert Memorial, a monument of pure signification. The soundtrack, composed by Michael Nyman, consists of a montage of voices, and is composed of Victorian quotations and modern analyses, together with the bemused speculation of a couple of American tourists.

results.title: Frozen II
results.creator_credit: Lisa Keene, Jennifer Lee, Chris Buck, Walt Disney Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Elsa, Anna, Kristoff and Olaf head far into the forest to learn the truth about an ancient mystery of their kingdom.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Keene, Jennifer Lee, Chris Buck, Walt Disney Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.description:
Disney’s fierce princess sisters Elsa and Anna are back in the sequel to the worldwide phenomenon Frozen (2013). Three years after saving Arendelle from Elsa’s uncontrollable, arctic powers and proving the love of family can warm the coldest hearts, the sisters learn of an enchanted forest whose elemental spirits are accidentally awakened to wreak havoc on their kingdom. To once again save the day, Elsa and Anna embark on an epic journey with Kristoff, Olaf and Sven to uncover the source of Elsa’s powers and discover a devastating family secret.

Building on the $1.2 billion dollar success of the first film, Frozen II (2018) likewise avalanched across the globe. With all the main cast reprising their roles, including Idina Menzel and Kristen Bell, and featuring brand-new songs, Frozen II became the second highest-grossing animated feature in history, just behind Disney’s The Lion King (2019).

Charting the growth of the princesses from the first film, the character designers came up with new looks (as well as the technology to make them) to demonstrate their evolution. The concept art above is an early illustration of a key scene where Elsa hears the siren song of the enchanted forest calling to her. As she’s awoken in the middle of the night, Elsa wears an ethereal magenta nightgown and her iconic braid from the first film appears more casual – after all, she’s been asleep. Small details are important. In the first film, when Elsa retreated from the world, her hair was tightly confined to a bun until she “Let It Go”. Likewise, Elsa’s hair becomes freer as she discovers more about herself after the performance of “Into the Unknown” from this scene.
description_for_label:
Disney’s fierce princess sisters Elsa and Anna are back in the sequel to the worldwide phenomenon Frozen (2013). Three years after saving Arendelle from Elsa’s uncontrollable, arctic powers and proving the love of family can warm the coldest hearts, the sisters learn of an enchanted forest whose elemental spirits are accidentally awakened to wreak havoc on their kingdom. To once again save the day, Elsa and Anna embark on an epic journey with Kristoff, Olaf and Sven to uncover the source of Elsa’s powers and discover a devastating family secret.

Building on the $1.2 billion dollar success of the first film, Frozen II (2018) likewise avalanched across the globe. With all the main cast reprising their roles, including Idina Menzel and Kristen Bell, and featuring brand-new songs, Frozen II became the second highest-grossing animated feature in history, just behind Disney’s The Lion King (2019).

Charting the growth of the princesses from the first film, the character designers came up with new looks (as well as the technology to make them) to demonstrate their evolution. The concept art above is an early illustration of a key scene where Elsa hears the siren song of the enchanted forest calling to her. As she’s awoken in the middle of the night, Elsa wears an ethereal magenta nightgown and her iconic braid from the first film appears more casual – after all, she’s been asleep. Small details are important. In the first film, when Elsa retreated from the world, her hair was tightly confined to a bun until she “Let It Go”. Likewise, Elsa’s hair becomes freer as she discovers more about herself after the performance of “Into the Unknown” from this scene.
